Similar proofs.
Mathematical induction is often stated with the starting value 0 (rather than 1). In fact, it will work just as well with a variety of starting values. Here is an example when the starting value is 3: "The sum of the interior angles of a formula_1-sided polygon is formula_1 degrees."
The initial starting value is 3, and the interior angles of a triangle is formula_1 degrees.
Assume that the interior angles of a formula_1-sided polygon is formula_1 degrees. Add on a triangle which makes the figure a formula_1-sided polygon, and that increases the count of the angles by 180 degrees formula_1 degrees. Since both the base case and the inductive case are handled, the proof is now complete.
There are a great many mathematical objects for which proofs by mathematical induction works. The technical term is a "well-ordered set".
Inductive definition.
The same idea can work to "define" a set of objects, as well as to prove statements about that set of objects.
There is a set of axioms for the arithmetic of the natural numbers which is based on mathematical induction. This is called "Peano's Axioms". The undefined symbols are | and =.
